comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
This photo is entitled elsewhere as Hacienda de San Diego about half March.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: you can see a colored picture of this building (recently taken [with the name HDASAND 1]) in www.flickr.com/photos/sanfelipeelreal/2800678650/

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
If you go to Goole Maps in satelite or map views go aproximately 12 miles south from Casas Grandes  and 3 miles west, aside from Peña Dorada, you'll find pictures of this building as the main house (casco de hacienda) of Hacienda de San Diego as it was its real name.  There you can check that name engraved in the big medallion on the front porch. Could it be that Madero was here before beeing in Bustillos after his defeat in Casas Grandes on March 6, 1911, or he advanced from here first  towards Casas Grandes and this picture is related to either?
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Dr. Roberto Duarte: Thank for pointing us to other photos of this building. Here is another recent picture where you can also see the front medallion which states : "Hacienda de San Diego": www.flickr.com/photos/betocisneros/2398489349/ We will add this information to the description when we update.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
Found an article in El Paso Herald, issue March 10, 1911 (The Library of Congress, Cronicling America ) in a subtitle "Rebels Gather Again":  "It is reported here this evening that Pascual Orozco and his band has arrived at San Diego ranch....."
It is stablished that Don Jacobo's ranch is San Diego (ranch) Hacienda.  Is it possible this picture reffers to the events and date above mentioned and the man on the white horse in the front center of the picture is Pascual Orozco Jr.? 
So far, I haven't found something that mentions a stay of Madero in San Diego Hacienda.
Dr. Roberto Duarte
Plastic Surgeon

comment.author: 74482999@N03
comment._content: Madero was indeed at the Hacienda de San Diego after his defeat at Casas Grandes.  The hacienda was one of Terrazo's.  Jacobo is Jacobo Anchondo, the manager of the site.  Orozco was not there with Madero.  Orozco, at this time was further south in Chihuahua doing his own thing.  The current residents of this hacienda are the grandson of the caretaker at the time of the revolution.  BTW, the left portico just collapsed in a rainstorm.  Castillo made the hacienda his headquarters during his time in charge of this area.  It is very close to Pearson, the Mormon colonies and Casas Grandes.  They have a great rodeo there each October!
